title: 110_hr3321
content: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to clarify that electronic surveillance directed at persons outside the United States is not considered surveillance under the Act. This includes additional procedures for authorizing acquisitions concerning individuals located outside the United States. The Director of National Intelligence and the Attorney General can authorize the acquisition of foreign intelligence information for up to one year on persons believed to be outside the US, as long as certain conditions are met. This does not constitute electronic surveillance and involves obtaining foreign intelligence. The Director of National Intelligence and the Attorney General can authorize the acquisition of foreign intelligence information from communications service providers or other persons for up to one year on individuals believed to be outside the US. This involves obtaining foreign intelligence with the purpose of minimization procedures being met. The Director of National Intelligence and the Attorney General can authorize the acquisition of foreign intelligence information without specifying the exact locations, with a written certification required within 72 hours unless immediate action is necessary. The Attorney General transmits certifications to the court under seal for review. The certification is kept secure and sealed unless needed for legality determination. Acquisitions must adhere to the Director of National Intelligence and Attorney General's certification and minimization procedures. The Director of National Intelligence and the Attorney General assess compliance with procedures for acquisitions and report to congressional committees. They may direct individuals to provide necessary information while maintaining secrecy and security measures approved by them. The Government compensates individuals for providing information, facilities, or assistance. The Attorney General can seek court intervention to enforce compliance with directives issued under subsection (e), with non-compliance potentially leading to contempt of court charges. The judicial district where a person can challenge the legality of a directive issued under subsection (e) by filing a petition with the designated judge. The judge will review the petition within 72 hours and determine if it is frivolous or not. If deemed frivolous, the petition will be denied, affirming the directive. The judge, within 72 hours, reviews petitions to modify or set aside a directive. If the directive is found unlawful, it may be modified or set aside; otherwise, it remains in effect. Appeals can be made to the Court of Review for further review. The Court of Review established under section 103(b) reviews decisions within 7 days. The Supreme Court can review decisions on petition for a writ of certiorari. Judicial proceedings must be expedited, and records are maintained securely. The Attorney General and the Director of National Intelligence oversee sealed petitions filed under this section. The court can review government submissions containing classified information ex parte and in camera. No liability exists for providing information in accordance with a directive under this section. Directives and orders made under this section must be retained for at least 10 years. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to include a new section for submission to court review of procedures. The Attorney General must submit procedures to the court for review within 120 days of enactment, ensuring acquisitions under section 105B are not electronic surveillance. The court will assess the Government's determination within 180 days, limited to whether it is clearly erroneous. The court will review the Government's procedures for acquisitions under section 105B within 180 days. If the determination is not clearly erroneous, the court will approve the continued use of the procedures. If it is clearly erroneous, the Government must submit new procedures within 30 days or cease acquisitions. The Government can appeal any court order to the court established under section 103(b), and the Supreme Court of the United States has jurisdiction to review such decisions. The court will review Government acquisitions under section 105B within 180 days. Acquisitions affected by the order may continue during any appeal, pending certiorari petition, and Supreme Court review. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to include a new section on reporting to Congress. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to include reporting to Congress on acquisitions under the new section. The Attorney General must inform select committees on intelligence and judiciary of both houses semi-annually about noncompliance incidents with directives issued for foreign intelligence acquisition. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to include reporting to Congress on acquisitions under the new section. The Attorney General and Director of National Intelligence must report on incidents of noncompliance with directives issued for foreign intelligence acquisition and the number of certifications and directives issued during the reporting period. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL AMENDMENT AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 includes changes to section 103(e) by updating references and adding a new item to the table of contents after section 105. SEC. 5. LIABILITY DEFENSE. No legal action or penalties can be imposed against any person for providing information or assistance to the intelligence community regarding classified communications intelligence activities from September 11, 2001, to the effective date of the Act, as long as certified by the Attorney General for protecting the United States from terrorism. The section aims to protect the United States from terrorist attacks and applies to all pending actions or claims. Actions in State courts are considered to arise under US laws and can be removed to federal court. Definitions include "intelligence community" and "person" as per specific laws. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PROCEDURES. The amendments made by this Act will take effect immediately after enactment. Existing orders under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 will remain in effect until expiration, with the option to be reauthorized if justified. New applications can also be filed under the same provisions. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 allows for the granting of applications that meet its requirements. The court can extinguish existing authorizations for surveillance upon request. Surveillance conducted under this subsection must adhere to the provisions of the Act.
